critique: This executive order establishes a Consumer Affairs Council to coordinate federal consumer programs. It aims to improve management, efficiency, and interagency cooperation in consumer-related activities. It mandates agencies to review and revise procedures to consider consumer needs, establish consumer participation mechanisms, provide informational materials, educate staff, and handle complaints effectively. The order also designates senior officials within each agency to oversee consumer activities and requires agencies to submit consumer program exhibits in their budget submissions. It also directs the Office of Personnel Management to consult with the Council on civil service initiatives related to consumer affairs personnel. Overall, the order seeks to strengthen consumer protection and ensure that agencies adequately address consumer interests. It seems to expand federal oversight and intervention in consumer affairs across various agencies. There is little to suggest a strong ideological tilt. It seems to be a balanced approach to security and liberty. It does not seem to touch on immigration. It seems to favor federal control. It seems to expand executive power by creating a council and giving the chairperson significant authority. It seems to favor government intervention in the economy by mandating consumer programs and oversight. It seems to promote social inclusion by emphasizing consumer participation and addressing consumer needs.
